title: Spain recognizing Palestinian statehood was a big surprise
message:
Last summer, we joined the Touro University faculty on a Jewish history course comprised of a study abroad program in Spain and Portugal.
The course consisted of extensive lectures and practical fieldwork, visiting sites in both countries that were relevant not only to Jewish history but also to the current Jewish community.
Significant progress has been made there, and a modern Spanish Jewish community exists, but any attempt at memorializing their notorious Inquisition seems performative, at best.
To wit: In Spain, the Spanish Inquisition and its accompanying expulsion are memorialized by small, embedded wall plaques at several key locations.
Indeed, anti-Zionism isn’t antisemitism, until it is – and this includes the searing contempt with which Israel is treated because it is a Jewish state.
event_breakdown: The Spanish community of Madrid has elected a new mayor from the pro-Palestinian party, Guanyem, in a campaign focused on criticising Israel.

title: Jewish Culture Fest held Sunday in Providence
message:
Rhode Island's Jewish Culture Fest was held Sunday on Elmgrove Avenue, just outside the Jewish Community Center in Providence, hosted by the Jewish Alliance of Greater Rhode Island.
According to Adam Greenman, president and CEO of the Jewish Alliance, the first-of-its-kind event in the state was meant as a way to "celebrate everything we love about Jewish culture, in a time when antisemitism is rising."
ALSO SUNDAY IN PROVIDENCE:Greenman noted it was an opportunity to showcase "music, dance, art, comedy and, of course, the food,” adding, It is a lot harder to hate people when you have a better understanding of who they are, and that’s our goal.”The free event ran from 11 am to 6:30 pm.

According to Adam Greenman, president and CEO of the Jewish Alliance, the first-of-its-kind event in the state was meant as a way to "celebrate everything we love about Jewish culture, in a time when antisemitism is rising."

title: Online Learn - A - Thon Honoring Rabbi Riskin Will Focus on Jewish Values and Challenges
message:
Originally an innovation of the Covid-19 pandemic, Ohr Torah Stone’s online global pre-Shavuot Learn-a-Thon is set to happen on June 9 for the fifth year.
Rabbi Riskin immigrated to Israel from New York, and founded Ohr Torah Stone in 1983; now the organization has a network of 32 schools, education, and social justice programs in Israel and around the world.
Rabbi Sarel Rosenblatt, who leads OTS’s Beren-Machanaim Hesder Yeshiva, will discuss antisemitism and Islam, reflecting Ohr Torah Stone’s commitment to learning about and engaging with other religions.
Shavuot has an extra personal significance at Ohr Torah Stone as it is close to Rabbi Riskin’s birthday.
“Rabbi Riskin continues to be an inspiration, and his vision is a light to all of us at Ohr Torah Stone,” Rabbi Brander says.

title: A conversation for the times
message:
Browse > Home News / A conversation for the times – J-WireA conversation for the timesRead on for articleSky News Host Sharri Markson and Federal Opposition Leader Peter Dutton headlined “Behind the Scenes Conversation” at a sold-out function held at Sydney’s Moriah College.
JCA President Ian Sandler welcomed Senator Dave Sharma, Senator Sarah Henderson, Senator Holly Hughes, Julian Leeser, Kelly Sloan, Richard Shields, and guest of honour, Peter Dutton, who had come to Sydney especially for this event.
Ms Markson opened saying “We live in dark times at the moment, but I want today to be uplifting because there is reason for hope”.
In conclusion, Peter Dutton said that “the fight will never be over”.
In response to the question of whether support for Hamas is a breach of the law, Senator Sharma said, “It should be”.

title: Annual NYC parade for Israel draws thousands under heightened security measures
message:
An annual New York City parade for Israel that draws thousands of people kicked off Sunday with heightened security and a focus on solidarityThe parade comes almost eight months after the unprecedented Oct. 7 attack by Hamas, the deadliest in Israel's history.
Crowds of spectators lined the route of what this year is being called "Israel Day on Fifth."
There was never a thought of canceling the parade this year, Treyger said, despite what he termed an astronomical rise in antisemitism.
That includes drones, K-9 units, bike patrols, fencing and barriers and designated entry points for spectators all along the parade route.
We're not going to allow any unlawfulness and any disruption of any celebration of one's heritage in this city," New York City Mayor Eric Adams said at a security briefing.
